newsitem.title: GERMANY: Daimler reports convincing return to profit in 96.
newsitem.headline: Daimler reports convincing return to profit in 96.

text.p: German industrial gaint Daimler-Benz AG on Wednesday announced a convincing return to profitability in 1996 after posting the largest loss in German corporate history in 1995.
Daimler said in a brief statement that 1996 net income climbed to 2.8 billion marks ($1.66 billion), up from a 5.7 billion-mark ($3.38 billion) loss the year before.
Company operating income, meanwhile, climbed to 2.4 billion marks ($1.42 billion) from a 1.10 billion-mark ($650 million) loss the year before.
Daimler said the improved results would allow it to pay a dividend of 1.10 marks (65 cents) per share after failing to pay a dividend in 1995 for the first time in decades.
Sales climbed to 106.3 billion marks ($63.05 billion) in 1996 from 103.55 billion marks ($61.42 billion) the year before.

Daimler's loss in 1995 was due largely to huge restructuring charges associated with streamlining at its aircraft unit Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG (DASA) and the breakup of rail and engineering unit AEG AG.
Daimler stock surged in after-market trade to an all-time high of 136.00 marks ($80.66) after the announcement before settling back to trade at 125.40 marks ($74.38), a 4.2 percent gain on the day.
Analysts had expected company net profit to exceed 2 billion marks ($1.19 billion), but were surprised at the extent of the earnings improvement.
"The figures were huge," one stock trader said.
Daimler said in its statement that net income was higher than operating profit due partly to one-time tax factors.
